title: How to Make Tempura

steps.headline: Place about a cup of ice water in a medium-sized mixing bowl.
Stir in one large egg.
steps.description: Remove the egg from the refrigerator just before adding, as the egg should be well-chilled.

steps.headline: Stir 3/4 cup of flour and 1/8 teaspoon of baking soda into the egg mixture.
Mix the batter lightly and don't worry about a few small lumps of unmixed flour.
steps.description: Too much mixing will result in doughy, non-crispy tempura.

steps.headline: Keep the tempura batter in the refrigerator while you prepare the foods for frying.
Prepare the foods for frying in the tempura batter ahead of time.
steps.description: If you are making fish tempura, wash and debone the fish, then cut the fish into small chunks. If you are using shrimp in your tempura, the shrimp should be de-veined.

steps.headline: Use the freshest, firmest vegetables you can find to make vegetable tempura.
Cut the vegetables into chunks.
steps.description: Avoid soft vegetables, as soft vegetables will become soggy when the vegetables are deep-fried.

steps.headline: Pat the food dry with paper towels.
steps.description: Place the food in the refrigerator until you're ready to deep fry.

steps.headline: Set the bowl of homemade tempura batter in a larger bowl filled with ice water.
steps.description: Tempura batter should be kept cold while you work.

steps.headline: Season the cut veggies.
steps.description: This will add flavor to the food, and also wick away moisture, making the batter stick better.

steps.headline: Place 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of cooking oil in a heavy frying pan.
steps.description: You can use nearly any type of oil, including canola, safflower, corn or peanut oil. However, avoid olive oil, which will alter the flavor of the tempura. If you are using a deep fat fryer, fill the fryer to the level recommended by the manufacturer.

steps.headline: Heat the oil to 350 degrees.
steps.description: If you don't have a thermometer, heat the oil then drop about a pea-sized bit of batter into the oil. If the oil is hot enough, the batter will drop to the bottom before it sizzles and bounces quickly to the top of the oil.

steps.headline: Using your hands or chopsticks, dip the prepared food into the tempura batter, making sure to coat it on all sides.
steps.description: It is helpful to place your batter near the oil so you don't spill on the counter when moving it to the oil.

steps.headline: Move the battered food directly from the bowl of batter into the hot oil.
steps.description: Remember to place it in the oil gently so it does not splash.

steps.headline: Turn each piece once so the food cooks evenly on both sides.
steps.description: Cook the tempura until the batter is golden brown.

steps.headline: Remove the fried tempura with tongs, then place on a layer of folded paper towels.

tyn: Heavy frying pan or medium-large deep fryer
text: Making the batter Place about a cup of ice water in a medium-sized mixing bowl.  Stir in one large egg. Remove the egg from the refrigerator just before adding, as the egg should be well-chilled. Stir 3/4 cup of flour and 1/8 teaspoon of baking soda into the egg mixture.  Mix the batter lightly and don't worry about a few small lumps of unmixed flour. Too much mixing will result in doughy, non-crispy tempura. Keep the tempura batter in the refrigerator while you prepare the foods for frying.  Preparing the dipping ingredients Prepare the foods for frying in the tempura batter ahead of time. If you are making fish tempura, wash and debone the fish, then cut the fish into small chunks. If you are using shrimp in your tempura, the shrimp should be de-veined. Use the freshest, firmest vegetables you can find to make vegetable tempura. Wash the vegetables thoroughly. Cut the vegetables into chunks. Avoid soft vegetables, as soft vegetables will become soggy when the vegetables are deep-fried. Pat the food dry with paper towels. Place the food in the refrigerator until you're ready to deep fry. Frying Set the bowl of homemade tempura batter in a larger bowl filled with ice water. Tempura batter should be kept cold while you work. Season the cut veggies. This will add flavor to the food, and also wick away moisture, making the batter stick better. Place 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of cooking oil in a heavy frying pan. You can use nearly any type of oil, including canola, safflower, corn or peanut oil. However, avoid olive oil, which will alter the flavor of the tempura. If you are using a deep fat fryer, fill the fryer to the level recommended by the manufacturer. Heat the oil to 350 degrees. If you don't have a thermometer, heat the oil then drop about a pea-sized bit of batter into the oil. If the oil is hot enough, the batter will drop to the bottom before it sizzles and bounces quickly to the top of the oil. Using your hands or chopsticks, dip the prepared food into the tempura batter, making sure to coat it on all sides. It is helpful to place your batter near the oil so you don't spill on the counter when moving it to the oil. Move the battered food directly from the bowl of batter into the hot oil. Remember to place it in the oil gently so it does not splash. Turn each piece once so the food cooks evenly on both sides. Cook the tempura until the batter is golden brown. Remove the fried tempura with tongs, then place on a layer of folded paper towels.  Finished.
sentences: Making the batter Place about a cup of ice water in a medium-sized mixing bowl.
Stir in one large egg.
Remove the egg from the refrigerator just before adding, as the egg should be well-chilled.
Stir 3/4 cup of flour and 1/8 teaspoon of baking soda into the egg mixture.
Mix the batter lightly and don't worry about a few small lumps of unmixed flour.
Too much mixing will result in doughy, non-crispy tempura.
Keep the tempura batter in the refrigerator while you prepare the foods for frying.
Preparing the dipping ingredients Prepare the foods for frying in the tempura batter ahead of time.
If you are making fish tempura, wash and debone the fish, then cut the fish into small chunks.
If you are using shrimp in your tempura, the shrimp should be de-veined.
Use the freshest, firmest vegetables you can find to make vegetable tempura.
Wash the vegetables thoroughly.
Cut the vegetables into chunks.
Avoid soft vegetables, as soft vegetables will become soggy when the vegetables are deep-fried.
Pat the food dry with paper towels.
Place the food in the refrigerator until you're ready to deep fry.
Frying Set the bowl of homemade tempura batter in a larger bowl filled with ice water.
Tempura batter should be kept cold while you work.
Season the cut veggies.
This will add flavor to the food, and also wick away moisture, making the batter stick better.
Place 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of cooking oil in a heavy frying pan.
You can use nearly any type of oil, including canola, safflower, corn or peanut oil.
However, avoid olive oil, which will alter the flavor of the tempura.
If you are using a deep fat fryer, fill the fryer to the level recommended by the manufacturer.
Heat the oil to 350 degrees.
If you don't have a thermometer, heat the oil then drop about a pea-sized bit of batter into the oil.
If the oil is hot enough, the batter will drop to the bottom before it sizzles and bounces quickly to the top of the oil.
Using your hands or chopsticks, dip the prepared food into the tempura batter, making sure to coat it on all sides.
It is helpful to place your batter near the oil so you don't spill on the counter when moving it to the oil.
Move the battered food directly from the bowl of batter into the hot oil.
Remember to place it in the oil gently so it does not splash.
Turn each piece once so the food cooks evenly on both sides.
Cook the tempura until the batter is golden brown.
Remove the fried tempura with tongs, then place on a layer of folded paper towels.
Finished.
